;;2023-10-06T03:36:52Z;
;
;;一架正在飞行的塞斯纳飞机。
;

;一名纽约男子对以下指控表示无罪：通过驾驶小型飞机飞越一名妇女的家来跟踪她。

;

;65 岁的迈克尔·阿诺德 (Michael Arnold) 在佛蒙特州南部（他的飞机停在那里）被提审，罪名是严重跟踪、违反防止虐待令、拒捕，妨碍公职人员并向警方提供虚假信息。

;

;他被释放的条件有几个，包括他不能与该女子接触，不跟踪她，并与她保持 300 英尺（91 米）的距离家庭和公司，以及所有飞机上。

;

;一名联邦调查局特工表示，阿诺德跟踪这位纽约州斯凯勒维尔的女子大约四年了。一项跟踪令禁止他乘坐飞机。据佛蒙特州本宁顿的调查官员称，纽约当局称阿诺德被发现低空飞过斯凯勒维尔村上空，并一度被观察到从飞机上扔西红柿。

;

;这名女子告诉警方，她担心法庭文件称，长期以来一直担心她的安全，并担心阿诺德会驾驶他的飞机进入她的家。她告诉当地媒体，阿诺德是她拥有的咖啡馆的顾客。

;
;

;;相关：;;“一开始我试图保持礼貌，不要伤害他的感情”：社交媒体上的常客如何成为我的跟踪者;

;
;

;阿诺德周二在抵达佛蒙特州本宁顿的威廉·莫尔斯州立机场时被捕，他在那里存放着他的 1976 年塞斯纳 180 单引擎飞机。警方称，他说自己没有跟踪任何人，并否认自己前一天驾驶过飞机，而是说自己和某人一起乘坐飞机。根据宣誓书，阿诺德告诉警官，他与这名女子没有接触，如果他想伤害她，他可以很容易地做到这一点，但他从未这样做过。

;

;他说联邦调查局证词称，航空管理局没有告诉他他不能飞行，他飞越斯凯勒维尔是为了为他们的 Facebook 社区页面拍照。斯凯勒维尔位于本宁顿机场西北约 30 英里（48 公里）处。

;

;5 月 30 日，纽约州萨拉托加镇法院的一名法官向阿诺德发出了临时保护令，要求阿诺德远离这名女子根据警方的证词，她的住所、公司和工作地点。宣誓书称，他被命令不得与她联系，不得骚扰、恐吓、威胁或以其他方式干扰她、她的家人或家庭成员以及涉嫌犯罪的证人。

;

;阿诺德还被要求根据该命令停止飞行任何飞机，该命令在 11 月 30 日开庭之前一直有效。

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 13:22:01 +0800 South Sudan ‘attacking’ journalists and activists who criticise the statehttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/06/south-sudan-attacking-journalists-and-activists-who-criticise-the-state
;;2023-10-06T04:00:33Z;
;
;;一名男子阅读《朱巴监视器》，该报报道了南苏丹记者彼得·莫伊于 2015 年 8 月 20 日在朱巴被谋杀的情况。
;

;根据 ;联合国南苏丹人权委员会;警告说，对自由的压制可能会妨碍该国在 2024 年举行可信选举的能力。

;

;周四发布的;57页报告;，包括近 100 起国家支持的侵犯人权行为，包括恐吓、骚扰、暴力、任意拘留和酷刑，以及针对女记者的性暴力。该委员会表示，这些报告得到了独立调查的证实。

;

;“国家正在攻击记者、活动人士甚至普通公民——任何敢于讨论当局可能认为敏感或批评其立场的问题的人”，专员巴尼·阿法科 (Barney Afako) 说道。 “[这种]待遇严重破坏了南苏丹的和平与民主化前景。”

;

;报告详细介绍了该国国家安全局对媒体和民间社会活动的侵入性监视和干扰，包括安全当局的要求了解这些团体举行的任何会议和研讨会的详细信息，以及参加人员的名单。

;

;报告发现，安全官员经常出席此类会议和全国各地的新闻编辑室，在那里他们进行监视和镇压批评政府的信息。该委员会表示，独立媒体机构也未能幸免，并报道了网络攻击和网站封锁事件。

;

;“这些攻击的目的和效果是阻止对关键信息的访问并扼杀公众辩论和讨论，阿法科说，并补充说反对派领导人还报告称需要获得同意才能举行公众集会。南苏丹政府发言人没有立即回应置评请求。

;

;南苏丹正在为 2024 年 12 月举行选举做准备，这是自 2011 年艰苦奋斗从苏丹独立以来的首次选举。对他们的新国家寄予厚望，但它陷入了忠于该国总统萨尔瓦·基尔和反对派领袖、第一副总统里克·马查尔的派系之间的旷日持久的内战，这场内战沿着种族界限展开。

;

;2018 年，两国领导人签署了一项和平协议，结束了敌对行动，但和平仍然脆弱，协议下的重要改革已陷入停滞，包括独立司法机构和新宪法的计划。

;

;联合国委员会已警告说，政府对媒体、民间社会和批评者的打压正在扼杀选举前的言论和集会自由，这与喀土穆政权时期所使用的策略如出一辙，当时该国还是苏丹的一部分。

;

;< a href="https://www.hrw.org/news/2023/02/20/south-sudanese-refugee-goes-missing-kenya">;莫里斯·马比奥;，南苏丹政府批评者， 2 月份，他在肯尼亚首都内罗毕的家中被绑架，并被带到朱巴拘留，据报道他仍​​留在那里。尚未对他提起诉讼。
;
;“这是一个悲剧性的讽刺，在一个独立的南苏丹，现在执政的解放者无法容忍公众监督、批评观点和政治反对派……这与南苏丹人渴望的民主治理和进程背道而驰。”阿法科说。

;

;联合国表示，其采访的许多记者和活动人士都实行自我审查，并回避重要的公共利益报道。对;缺乏透明度的调查; 在该国石油财富的管理方面尤其敏感，审查政府在该国面临的人道主义危机中所采取行动的报道也尤为敏感，其中大致 ;估计有 76 ;% 的人口需要人道主义援助.

;
;

;;相关：;;南苏丹家庭在试图返回家园时陷入困境;

;
;

;近年来，南苏丹也面临<创纪录的洪水导致数十万人流离失所。活动人士告诉《卫报》，公民空间的缩小令人担忧，他们经常担心自己的生命和安全。 “任何敢于发声的人都可能遭到酷刑或杀害。这些案件对我们来说并不新鲜。”流亡活动人士保罗·邓*说道。

;

;委员会呼吁南苏丹政府停止骚扰记者、维权人士和民间社会团体，并加强监督其安全部门表示，迫切需要就和平协议采取行动，包括司法改革和宪法制定，并在报告中警告说：“在没有解决安全问题、创造有利环境和不解决安全问题的情况下举行选举，完成技术安排可能会加剧不满并加剧进一步的暴力。”

;

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 13:22:01 +0800 ‘Choose London’: Sadiq Khan steps up efforts to lure EU citizens post-Brexithttps://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/oct/06/london-sadiq-khan-eu-citizens-uk-capital-brexit-mayor
;;2023-10-06T04:00:32Z;
;
;;萨迪克·汗参加伦敦骄傲游行。
;

;伦敦市长敦促欧盟公民“选择伦敦”而不是其他欧洲城市，承诺尽管英国脱欧，仍将使英国首都成为一个更好的生活和工作场所。

;

;萨迪克·汗告诉《卫报》，自英国脱欧以来，他已加倍努力吸引欧盟公民尽管存在签证要求等新障碍，但还是离开了欧盟。

;

;“这就是我肩负重大责任的地方。我必须让你选择伦敦（而不是）更具吸引力，而不是法兰克福、巴黎或都柏林，”他说。

;

;“我必须确保我们的夜生活、我们的博物馆、由于自由流动，我们的画廊、我们的价值观、我们能提供的东西胜过前往另一个欧洲城市的便利。”

; ;

;他引用了最近备受瞩目的体育和文化活动，从流行的 Abba Voyage 节目到美国职业棒球大联盟。

;

;指出汗补充道，有 100 万欧盟公民居住在伦敦：“我们可能已经脱离了欧盟这个国家，但伦敦是一座欧洲城市，我认为它是欧洲的首都。”

;

;欧盟公民可以获得资格如果雇主招聘他们从事高收入职位（通常收入超过 26,200 英镑），则可以获得英国工作签证，但在欧盟内部，他们可以免签证四处流动。

;

;同时也会造成实际障碍，汗承认英国退出欧盟的决定改变了整个欧洲对英国的看法，这让他在宣传伦敦作为目的地方面面临着更加艰巨的任务。

;

;“作为英国人，我们必须接受这一点我们离开欧盟已经在包括欧盟在内的世界各地引起了人们对我们的看法的冲击波——公平还是不公平，”他说。

;

;注意到学校旅行的数量急剧下降由于儿童不再能够在没有护照的情况下旅行、欧盟大学学生人数下降以及到欧洲大陆巡演的英国乐队减少，工党市长还对几十年来建立的文化联系正在受到侵蚀表示担忧。

;

;他说：“当你进入欧盟委员会并与政治家交谈时，或者当你与欧洲大陆的首席执行官交谈时，他们中的很多人都非常了解伦敦。他们在这里学习，他们在这里旅行，他们在这里进行对外交流，他们爱上了这座城市。这意味着他们想在这里投资。这意味着他们想来这里度假。这意味着他们想在这里做生意。”

; ;

;可汗担心，随着时间的推移，诸如此类的接触会减少这些可能会产生负面影响，不仅对经济，而且对英国的价值观。

;

;他说：“我们这一代人是宽容的，我们是尊重的。仇外心理更少，偏执更少。其中很大一部分是熟悉，因为我们必须知道意大利食物实际上并不算太糟糕，它很棒;我们必须听西班牙音乐；我们必须和法国人交朋友。这就是我对这些联系感到担忧的地方。

;

;“无论是求爱、友谊还是商业伙伴，这都让事情变得更加困难。”

;

;Khan 为之感到自豪他与欧洲市长的密切联系，其中包括巴黎的安妮·伊达尔戈、米兰的贝佩·萨拉和罗马的罗伯托·瓜尔蒂里。

;

;他与这些同行讨论的问题之一是空气质量。汗强烈捍卫伦敦最近扩建的;超低排放区;，保守党政府试图利用这一决定，首相里希·苏纳克 (Rishi Sunak) 声称在“向驾车者宣战”中站在处境艰难的司机一边。

;

;汗政府总部位于首都东部皇家码头的棱角分明的新市政厅大楼内，靠近巨大的 Excel 展览中心。落地窗让他可以一览快速发展的地区——在炎热的夏末，这里有滑水者和日光浴者。

; ;

;他正在连任，并面临 2024 年 5 月的连任之战，与大选不同，欧盟公民可以投票。

;

;最近的民意调查显示汗和”来自自由民主党或绿党选民的支持。

;

;;毫不掩饰作为英国脱欧的反对者，汗呼吁英国政治家就英国脱欧的后果以及如何减轻这些后果进行更公开的讨论，他认为这必须与欧盟的规则和实践更加一致。; p>;

;“令我心碎的是，在可预见的未来，我们不能谈论重新加入欧盟：公投往往是一代人一次，我尊重这一点。但即使我们的处境很糟糕，而且永远不会像在欧盟内部那样好，我们也必须尽力充分利用它。这意味着一致而不是分歧。”他说。

;
;

;;相关：;;英国脱欧指责游戏再次爆发：离开欧盟如何反过来咬保守党;< /p>;

;

;尽管他批评了英国政治中关于脱欧的“omertà”，但他对工党领袖基尔对此问题的谨慎表示了一些同情。

;

;“基尔，就像我是一个热情的留欧派，他必须让全国各地那些不确定我们是否相信我们所说的尊重英国公众投票的人放心。我明白了。我了解政治。”他说。

;

;上个月，保守党兴高采烈地抓住斯塔默的言论;“我们不想与欧盟分歧”; 。但汗坚称政客们不能永远回避这个话题。

;

;他说：“我不想造成分裂和僵局，也不想重新揭开旧伤，但我们已经谈论它。”

;

;就立即措施而言，特别是帮助缓解首都的技能短缺，汗支持酒店业提出的一项与欧盟互惠青年流动计划的提案。< /p>;

;这样的计划已经在澳大利亚和加拿大等少数国家实施，允许 18 至 35 岁的人在英国工作最多两年，反之亦然。

;

;这样的计划已经在澳大利亚和加拿大等少数国家实施。 >;

;汗说：“你与这座城市的任何企业交谈，他们都会告诉你他们存在技能短缺。你与世界上一些最好的餐馆老板和世界上一些最好的厨师交谈，他们无法因为爱和金钱而找到员工。”

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 13:22:01 +0800 Belgian intelligence investigating logistics hub of China’s Alibaba at local airporthttps://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/oct/06/belgian-intelligence-investigating-logistics-hub-of-chinas-alibaba-at-local-airport

;;一名男子走过阿里巴巴集团北京办公楼的标志。
;

;比利时该国国家安全局 (VSSE) 周四在一份声明中表示，官员们正在调查中国阿里巴巴集团控股公司在列日市货运机场存在的风险。

;

;在列日机场的欧洲物流中心，安全部门表示正在努力“侦查并打击阿里巴巴等中国实体可能进行的间谍和/或干扰活动”。

;

;比利时当局正在调查阿里巴巴的运营情况声明补充说，基于对中国法律框架的分析，阿里巴巴的存在“仍然构成了 VSSE 的关注点”，因为立法规定中国公司有义务与中国当局和情报部门共享数据。

;

;布鲁塞尔自由大学教授乔纳森·霍尔斯拉格 (Jonathan Holslag) 告诉英国《金融时报》，主要的担忧来源是阿里巴巴“以及其他几个物流平台，中国一直在向欧洲国家提出建议，让他们对供应链和最终的脆弱性有很多了解。”

;

;Holslag 表示，阿里巴巴的物流部门菜鸟也存在获取有关最终​​产品信息的风险。消费者。他说：“作为一个试图主导供应链的国家，了解消费模式的重要变化和物流链的知识对中国来说很有价值。”菜鸟在一份声明中表示，“我们强烈否认这些指控基于先前的推测。”

;

;“菜鸟遵守其运营所在地的所有法律法规。”

;

;阿里巴巴于 2018 年与比利时政府签署协议，开设一个由菜鸟运营的电子商务贸易中心，其中包括对物流基础设施的投资。

;

;这家中国电子商务公司上个月申请在香港证券交易所上市菜鸟，这将使该部门成为自阿里巴巴三月份表示将进行重组和分拆以来首个分拆将其业务分为六个部门;。

;
;;新西兰总理杰辛达·阿德恩于 2022 年 1 月 17 日接种了新冠疫苗。
;

;新西兰;受到全球赞扬的新冠疫情应对措施; 新研究显示，拯救了约 20,000 条生命。

;

;这份发表在《新西兰医学杂志》上的报告着眼于国家战略的影响，其中包括几乎完全关闭两个国家的国际边境数年的时间和一次数天或数周的严格封锁。

;

;结果是每百万人的新冠死亡率比美国低 80%。该报告还呼吁在大流行期间采取一些预防措施，包括在医疗机构中继续戴口罩，以对抗新冠病毒和其他更常见的呼吸道感染，包括呼吸道合胞病毒和流感。

;

;“我会讨厌我们回到真正耸耸肩说，我们不关心[传染病]或者我们对此无能为力。这是宿命论，”奥塔哥大学教授迈克尔·贝克 (Michael Baker) 说道，他在新西兰应对流感大流行方面发挥了重要作用，也是该报告的 16 位合著者之一。

;
;

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 10:52:01 +0800 Labour beats SNP in Rutherglen and Hamilton West byelectionhttps://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/oct/06/labour-beats-snp-in-rutherglen-and-hamilton-west-byelection-michael-shanks

;;Michael Shanks and Scottish Labour Leader Anas Sarwar arrive at the Rutherglen and Hamilton West by-election count.
;

;Scottish Labour's Michael Shanks has won the Rutherglen and Hamilton West byelection, in a resounding victory over the SNP that the party hopes will have a “seismic” impact across the UK.

;

;In a win that UK Labour leader, Keir Starmer, predicted would be a “milestone” on his party's “hard road back to power”, Shanks beat his closest rival, the SNP's Katy Loudon, by 17,845 votes to 8,399 – a majority of 9,446.

;

;Turnout on Thursday was 37.19% compared with 66.5% at the last general election in 2019, in the seat to the south-east of Glasgow that has now changed hands four times between the SNP and Labour since 2010.

; ;

;The victory provides the UK Labour leader, Keir Starmer with a boost days before the party gathers for its autumn conference in Liverpool. Senior figures are convinced that revived fortunes in Scotland can send a message UK-wide about the party's electability before the next general election.

;

;“People need change from governments that have too often been distracted,” Shanks said, after the win was announced.
;
; “People are once again listening to the Scottish Labour Party … Change is possible.”

;

;During the campaign Shanks, a modern studies teacher at a local high school, said people were desperate for “a fresh start” after constituents voted for the Covid rule-breaking MP Margaret Ferrier to be removed from her seat.

;

;Ferrier, who sat as an independent after she was suspended from the SNP, was convicted of breaking travel rules during lockdown and later suspended from the Commons for 30 days.

;

;The Labour leadership considered this byelection a crucial test of an apparent turnaround in Scottish politics since Nicola Sturgeon's resignation in February.

;

;On the final day of campaigning the Scottish Labour leader, Anas Sarwar, said: “I believe this has the potential to be a seismic byelection and then as a launchpad as we head towards that next general election.”

;

;Polls suggest the SNP's dominance is diminishing as the party struggles with questions of transparency and governance linked to the police investigation into its financial conduct, with Labour the beneficiary.

;

;With no clear route to a second independence referendum and the public overwhelmed by cost of living concerns, there are strong indications that Scottish voters are now less likely to choose which party to back based on their constitutional preferences.

;

;Shanks's campaign focused on the cost of living crisis, attacking the SNP government at Holyrood's record on public services.

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 09:22:02 +0800 Memorial honors trailblazing senator Dianne Feinstein: ‘she was a lioness’https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/oct/05/senator-dianne-feinstein-san-francisco-city-hall-memorial
;;2023-10-06T00:35:44Z;
;
;;An image of the late senator Dianne Feinstein is displayed during her memorial service outside San Francisco's city hall on 5 October 2023.
;

;At a memorial for Dianne Feinstein on Thursday, Joe Biden praised the late senator as a dear friend and a woman of deep integrity who fought to protect what was important to the US: freedom, civil liberties, security and the constitution.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Dianne Feinstein's historic career began in tragedy and ended in controversy;

;
;

;“She was always tough, prepared, rigorous, compassionate. She always served the people of California and our nation for the right reasons,” Biden said in recorded video remarks played at the memorial outside San Francisco city hall.

;

;Roughly 1,500 invited guests were at the private service, where two large screens showed photos of Feinstein over the years. Guests seated in white chairs sweltered on an unseasonably hot day as the US navy's Blue Angels flight team soared overhead, occasionally interrupting speakers with the roar of their jets.

;

;The flight demonstration squadron is in the city as part of Fleet Week, an annual San Francisco celebration started by Feinstein in 1981 when she was mayor.

;

;The vice-president Kamala Harris and Senate majority leader Chuck Schumer were among those delivering remarks, along with Feinstein's granddaughter, Eileen Mariano.

;

;California's governor Gavin Newsom, a former San Francisco mayor, and former governor Jerry Brown were in the audience.

;

;The service marks the end of two days of events in the city that launched Feinstein's political career.

; ;

;On Wednesday, hundreds of mourners streamed into city hall to pay their respects, honoring Feinstein as fearless, smart and the glue who kept the city together after two shocking political assassinations.

;

;Many said they had never met her, but wanted to honor an indefatigable public servant who fought to level the playing field for women, members of the LGBTQ+ community and racial minorities.

;

;Feinstein died early Friday at her home in Washington DC of natural causes, said Adam Russell, a spokesperson for her office. She was 90.

;

;Feinstein was one of California's first two women US senators, a job she first won alongside Barbara Boxer in 1992, dubbed the “Year of the Woman”.

;

;Feinstein spent much of her career in the senate but will be known as the forever mayor of San Francisco, a role she inherited in tragedy. She was president of the board of supervisors in November 1978 when a former supervisor assassinated mayor George Moscone and supervisor Harvey Milk, the city's first openly gay supervisor, at city hall.

;

;Feinstein, who found Milk's body, became acting mayor and won election twice to serve as mayor until 1988.

;

;Georgia Otterson, 76, a health care administrator, said Feinstein wasn't as politically liberal as she would have liked, but the late mayor earned her respect with how she kept the heartbroken city together.

;

;“We were all mourning together, holding candles. If memory serves me, Joan Baez sang,” Otterson said of an impromptu march that night from the historically gay Castro district to city hall. “And she held us up.”

;

;As a centrist Democrat, Feinstein was criticized by people on the left, including for her support of the death penalty, and in her later years, for working with Republicans. But the straight, white woman largely earned the gratitude of a city that celebrates its racial and sexual diversity.

;

;She steered San Francisco through the HIV and Aidcrisis, bringing attention to an epidemic ignored by President Ronald Reagan. She also secured federal and private funding to save the city's iconic cable cars from death by deterioration.

;

;Feinstein led the city as it played host to the Democratic national convention in 1984. Another San Francisco tradition – “Fleet Week” – was started by Feinstein in 1981, and this year's annual celebration of air shows, naval ships and military bands is dedicated to her.

; ;

;While Feinstein's career sent her to Washington, she remained deeply involved in the affairs of San Francisco, the city where she was born and raised. She often called her successors – including Newsom – to complain about potholes or trash and to offer advice and encouragement.

;

;Breed recalled looking up to Feinstein when she was a Black kid growing up in public housing and playing the french horn in a middle school band that performed regularly at mayoral events.

;

;“She was so proud of us and she said so, and she took the time to talk to us, express how amazing we were and to remind us that we were her band,” Breed said at a news conference the day after Feinstein's death.

;

;Mourners on Wednesday expressed their pride in Feinstein.

;

;“She kept moving on up.我为她感到骄傲，非常为她感到骄傲，”81 岁的退休联邦政府雇员多萝西·哈德森 (Dorothy Hudson) 说道。 “她非常善良，非常聪明。 She opened doors up to let people know: 'you can do it.'”

;

;San Francisco native Cari Donovan placed a bouquet of red and pink lilies and daisies on the floor before the casket. She lingered, crying quietly over a woman she never knew, but who was so important to her life.

;

;“She championed and fought for the rights of so many people,” Donovan said. “我非常感激。 And I really just wanted her family to know how much she meant to me.”

;

;The social worker said she talked to her 28-year-old daughter about the battles Feinstein fought so that younger generations of women could dream bigger. “She was a lioness.”

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 08:22:01 +0800 Extreme weather displaced 43m children in past six years, Unicef reportshttps://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2023/oct/05/extreme-weather-climate-crisis-displaced-children-unicef-report
;;2023-10-05T23:01:25Z;
;
;;Children at a camp for displaced people due to Cyclone Biparjoy in Badin, Pakistan's southern district in the Sindh province, on 15 June 2023.
;

;At least 43 million child displacements were linked to extreme weather events over the past six years, the equivalent of 20,000 children being forced to abandon their homes and school every single day, new research has found.

;

;Floods and storms accounted for 95% of recorded child displacement between 2016 and 2021, according to the first-of-its-kind analysis by Unicef and the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC). The rest – more than 2 million children – were displaced by wildfires and drought.

;
;

;;Related: ;;UN report urges global end to fossil fuel exploration by 2030;

;
;

;Displacement is traumatic and frightening regardless of age, but the consequences can be especially disruptive and damaging for children who may miss out on education, life-saving vaccines and social networks.

;

;“It is terrifying for any child when a ferocious wildfire, storm or flood barrels into their community,” said Unicef executive director Catherine Russell. “For those forced to flee, the fear and impact can be especially devastating, with worry of whether they will return home, resume school or be forced to move again.”

;

;In absolute terms, China, the Philippines and India dominate with 22.3 million child displacements – just over half the total number – which the report attributes to the countries' geographical exposure to extreme weather such as monsoon rains and cyclones and large child populations, as well as increased pre-emptive evacuations.

;

;But the greatest proportion of child displacements were in small island states – many of which are facing existential threats due to the climate emergency – and in the Horn of Africa where conflict, extreme weather, poor governance and resource exploitation overlap.

;

;A staggering 76% of children were displaced in the small Caribbean island of Dominica, which was devastated by Hurricane Maria in 2017, a category 4 Atlantic storm that damaged 90% of the island's housing stock. Storms also led to more than a quarter of children being displaced in Cuba, Vanuatu, Saint Martin and the Northern Mariana Islands.

;

;Somalia and South Sudan recorded the most child displacements due to floods, affecting 12% and 11% of the child population respectively.

; ;

;;Children Displaced in a Changing Climate; is the first global analysis of the children driven from their homes due to floods, storms, droughts and wildfires, and comes as weather-related disasters are becoming more intense, destructive and unpredictable due to fossil-fuel driven global heating.

;

;The report's stark numbers are almost certainly an undercount due to major gaps in reporting drought and slow onset climate impacts such as rising sea level, desertification and rising temperatures.

;

;“This is absolutely a conservative estimate, and possibly just the tip of the iceberg for some climate impacts,” said Verena Knaus, the Unicef lead on global migration and displacement. “Climate is the fastest-growing driver of child displacement yet most policies and discussions about climate finance fail to consider or prioritize children.”

;

;;In 2021, the International Energy Agency; (IEA) warned that there could be no further expansion of oil, gas and coal production if the world wanted to have any chance of avoiding catastrophic climate breakdown. The world failed to heed the warning, and emission cuts are wildly off track, according to the ;recent UN global stocktake;, the most comprehensive analysis of global climate action produced to date.

;

;In August 2022, unprecedented floods submerged a third of Pakistan underwater, causing billions of dollars in damage and displacing around 3.6 million children – many of whom went months without access to proper shelter, safe drinking water and sanitation. With every additional 1C of warming, the global risks of displacement from flooding ;are projected to rise by as much as 50%.;

;

;The Unicef analysis detected 1.3 million child displacements due to drought with Somalia, Ethiopia and Afghanistan by far the worst affected countries. Water scarcity forces people to move due to failed crops and to find drinking water for themselves and livestock, but the true scale of drought-migration is unknown as it is difficult to measure and radically underreported.

;

;Meanwhile, the US accounted for three quarters (610,000 out of 810,000) of child displacements linked to wildfires, with over half of the rest happening in Canada, Israel, Turkey and Australia. In the US, fires are increasingly linked to the expanding wildland urban interface (WUI), the zone between undeveloped wildland and human development, ;where more than 3,000 homes; and other buildings are lost annually.

;

;Earlier this year, entire communities were displaced by wildfires in Canada and Greece.

;

;Overall, children accounted for one in three of the 135 million global internal displacements that were linked to more than 8,000 weather-related disasters between 2016 and 2021 – and the toll is likely to get much worse, according to the report.

;

;Riverine floods pose the biggest future risk and could displace almost 96 million children over the next 30 years, according to the IDMC disaster displacement model. Based on current climate data, winds and storm surge could displace 10.3 million and 7.2 million children respectively over the same period, though this could be much worse if fossil fuels are not phased out urgently.

;

;Given their large populations, India, Bangladesh, Vietnam, the Philippines and China will likely have the most child displacements. In relative terms, children in the British Virgin Islands, the Bahamas, and Antigua and Barbuda are forecast to suffer most weather-disaster displacements over coming years.

;

;“The figures are extremely worrying and demonstrate the urgent need for states to recognise and plan for the link between climate change and displacement, to minimize long term health, education and other developmental impacts on displaced children,” said Adeline Neau, an Amnesty International researcher for Central America and Mexico.
